description: with huge wings Powdered skulls of and vicious vulture-like heads, the vrock are, for warriors killed in many, the archetypal demon. Amongst practitioners battle of the black art, they are seen as something of a Summoning watershed. A demonologist able to summon and Focus: A war control a vrock has survived many challenges in his banner at least one work without pushing himself too fast and is clearly hundred years old capable of proceeding further down the Dark Road through the summoning of the greatest demons of Glabrezu all. Vrocks are typically used as pure battle Despite being demons, capable of slaying hordes of lesser incredible attackers, be they mortal or demonic. This demon is opponents in 58 DEMONIC ENTITIES battle, the main strength of the glabrezu lies in subtlety. Just as the succubus tempts mortals with passion, the glabrezu beguiles them with dreams and promises of power in the material worlds. It takes a wily demonologist to fully realise this capability rather than merely sending the demon to destroy all around it. The glabrezu is to be considered for any practitioner who wants to ruin his enemies utterly, rather than destroy them outright, though this is likely to take a great many summoning rituals to accomplish as the demon is constantly called back to carry out the next part of a long, tortuous I and twisted plan of ruination. description: mind of any Summoning ritual foolish enough must begin at the to make a rise of a full moon mistake in a summoning Nalfeshnee ritual. Looking like a huge twenty feet tall cross between bear and boar, the nalfeshnee is amongst the strongest of all the Tana'ri and even a balor might reconsider attacking one without suitable advantages. They are incredibly bloodthirsty and yet prefer to outwit opponents over protracted periods of time rather than merely tearing them apart. Few can stand up to the fury of a nalfeshnee enraged but a demonologist may encounter additional problems in compelling this being into direct battle, such is its reluctance at times.
